abstract: A network service that broadcasts its availability using multicast DNS.
overview:
## Overview

The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class represents a network service, either one your application publishes or is a client of. This class and the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] class use multicast DNS to convey information about network services to and from your application. The API of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] provides a convenient way to publish the services offered by your application and to resolve the socket address for a service.

The types of services you access using [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] are the same types that you access directly using BSD sockets. HTTP and FTP are two services commonly provided by systems. (For a list of common services and the ports used by those services, see the file `/etc/services`.) Applications can also define their own custom services to provide specific data to clients.

You can use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class as either a publisher of a service or a client of a service. If your application publishes a service, your code must acquire a port and prepare a socket to communicate with clients. Once your socket is ready, you use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class to notify clients that your service is ready. If your application is the client of a network service, you can either create an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object directly (if you know the exact host and port information) or use an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] object to browse for services.

To publish a service, initialize your [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object with the service name, domain, type, and port information. All of this information must be valid for the socket created by your application. Once initialized, call the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/publish()] method to broadcast your service information to the network.

When connecting to a service, use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] class to locate the service on the network and obtain the corresponding [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object. Once you have the object, call the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/resolve(withTimeout:)] method to verify that the service is available and ready for your application. If it is, the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/addresses] property provides the socket information you can use to connect to the service.

The methods of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] operate asynchronously so your application is not impacted by the speed of the network. All information about a service is returned to your application through the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object’s delegate. You must provide a delegate object to respond to messages and to handle errors appropriately.

---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Foundation/NetService
crawled: 2025-12-04T16:24:43Z

# NetService

**Class**

A network service that broadcasts its availability using multicast DNS.

## Declaration

```swift
class NetService
```

## Overview

The [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class represents a network service, either one your application publishes or is a client of. This class and the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] class use multicast DNS to convey information about network services to and from your application. The API of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] provides a convenient way to publish the services offered by your application and to resolve the socket address for a service.

The types of services you access using [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] are the same types that you access directly using BSD sockets. HTTP and FTP are two services commonly provided by systems. (For a list of common services and the ports used by those services, see the file `/etc/services`.) Applications can also define their own custom services to provide specific data to clients.

You can use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class as either a publisher of a service or a client of a service. If your application publishes a service, your code must acquire a port and prepare a socket to communicate with clients. Once your socket is ready, you use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] class to notify clients that your service is ready. If your application is the client of a network service, you can either create an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object directly (if you know the exact host and port information) or use an [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] object to browse for services.

To publish a service, initialize your [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object with the service name, domain, type, and port information. All of this information must be valid for the socket created by your application. Once initialized, call the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/publish()] method to broadcast your service information to the network.

When connecting to a service, use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetServiceBrowser] class to locate the service on the network and obtain the corresponding [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object. Once you have the object, call the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/resolve(withTimeout:)] method to verify that the service is available and ready for your application. If it is, the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService/addresses] property provides the socket information you can use to connect to the service.

The methods of [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] operate asynchronously so your application is not impacted by the speed of the network. All information about a service is returned to your application through the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NetService] object’s delegate. You must provide a delegate object to respond to messages and to handle errors appropriately.

## Creating Network Services

- **init(domain:type:name:)**: Returns the receiver, initialized as a network service of a given type and sets the initial host information.
- **init(domain:type:name:port:)**: Initializes the receiver for publishing a network service of type `type` at the socket location specified by `domain`, `name`, and `port`.

## Configuring Network Services

- **data(fromTXTRecord:)**: Returns an `NSData` object representing a TXT record formed from a given dictionary.
- **dictionary(fromTXTRecord:)**: Returns a dictionary representing a TXT record given as an `NSData` object.
- **addresses**: A read-only array containing `NSData` objects, each of which contains a socket address for the service.
- **domain**: A string containing the domain for this service.
- **includesPeerToPeer**: Specifies whether to also publish, resolve, or monitor this service over peer-to-peer Bluetooth and Wi-Fi, if available.
- **getInputStream(_:outputStream:)**: Creates a pair of input and output streams for the receiver and returns a Boolean value that indicates whether they were retrieved successfully.
- **name**: A string containing the name of this service.
- **type**: The type of the published service.
- **txtRecordData()**: Returns the TXT record for the receiver.
- **setTXTRecord(_:)**: Sets the TXT record for the receiver, and returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the operation was successful.
- **delegate**: The delegate for the receiver.

## Managing Run Loops

- **schedule(in:forMode:)**: Adds the service to the specified run loop.
- **remove(from:forMode:)**: Removes the service from the given run loop for a given mode.

## Using Network Services

- **publish()**: Attempts to advertise the receiver’s on the network.
- **publish(options:)**: Attempts to advertise the receiver on the network, with the given options.
- **resolve()**: Starts a resolve process for the service.
- **resolve(withTimeout:)**: Starts a resolve process of a finite duration for the service.
- **port**: The port on which the service is listening for connections.
- **startMonitoring()**: Starts the monitoring of TXT-record updates for the receiver.
- **stop()**: Halts a currently running attempt to publish or resolve a service.
- **stopMonitoring()**: Stops the monitoring of TXT-record updates for the receiver.

## Obtaining the DNS Hostname

- **hostName**: A string containing the DNS hostname for this service.

## Constants

- **NSNetServices Errors**: If an error occurs, the delegate error-handling methods return a dictionary with the following keys.
- **NetService.ErrorCode**: These constants identify errors that can occur when accessing net services.
- **NetService.Options**: These constants specify options for a network service.

## Local Network Services

- **NetServiceDelegate**: The interface a net service uses to inform its delegate about the state of the service it offers.
- **NSBonjourServices**: Bonjour service types browsed by the app.
- **NSLocalNetworkUsageDescription**: A message that tells people why the app is requesting access to the local network.

## Inherits From

- NSObject

## Conforms To

- CVarArg
- CustomDebugStringConvertible
- CustomStringConvertible
- Equatable
- Hashable
- NSObjectProtocol
